content:
lass="word-wrap-span">This is a by-lass="word-wrap-span">invitation lass="word-wrap-span">commentary in a series on “lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s lass="word-wrap-span">Future,” part of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist ’s lass="word-wrap-span">Open lass="word-wrap-span">Future lass="word-wrap-span">initiative, which aims to lass="word-wrap-span">foster a global conversation across lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ideological spectrum on vital issues. lass="word-wrap-span">You can comment here or on Facebook and lass="word-wrap-span">Twitter . lass="word-wrap-span">More articles can be found at lass="word-wrap-span">Economist.com/lass="word-wrap-span">Openlass="word-wrap-span">Future

lass="word-wrap-span">NOT lass="word-wrap-span">THAT long ago, one of my principal concerns was lass="word-wrap-span">THAT, in the context of a world in lass="word-wrap-span">awe at the rising economic power and influence of lass="word-wrap-span">China, lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong was beginning to drop off the global radar. I have lass="word-wrap-span">always considered it vital lass="word-wrap-span">THAT the international community lass="word-wrap-span">NOT lose sight of lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s unique economic, social and political status under the concept of “one country, two systems”.

lass="word-wrap-span">Now that the recent social turmoil has captured the attention of the world’s media, the only comfort to be had is that the causes and significance of the protests are so widely understood overseas.

lass="word-wrap-span">Yet some myths still need to be lass="word-wrap-span">dispelled. lass="word-wrap-span">The protests are not lass="word-wrap-span">fundamentally directed against lass="word-wrap-span">China, but lass="word-wrap-span">They should be viewed against a lass="word-wrap-span">backdrop of increasingly lass="word-wrap-span">blatant lass="word-wrap-span">interference by lass="word-wrap-span">China’s central government in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">governance of lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong, a lass="word-wrap-span">creeping lass="word-wrap-span">erosion of lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s lass="word-wrap-span">autonomy and a progressive undermining of lass="word-wrap-span">cherished freedoms of speech, of lass="word-wrap-span">The press, lass="word-wrap-span">assembly and intellectual thought.

lass="word-wrap-span">Accusations that lass="word-wrap-span">The protests are being lass="word-wrap-span">fomented and funded by “foreign forces” are lass="word-wrap-span">entirely spurious. lass="word-wrap-span">The truth is that lass="word-wrap-span">The current protest movement is lass="word-wrap-span">entirely lass="word-wrap-span">homegrown and has developed some unique lass="word-wrap-span">class="word-wrap-span">haracteristics: a savvy use of lass="word-wrap-span">encrypted social media to organise and direct activity, excellent teamwork and lass="word-wrap-span">agile tactics. lass="word-wrap-span">Rallies and marches have been organised throughout lass="word-wrap-span">The territory to enable lass="word-wrap-span">The widest participation by lass="word-wrap-span">The genelass="word-wrap-span">Ral public.

lass="word-wrap-span">Recent events have led to a complete lass="word-wrap-span">breakdown of trust in the local lass="word-wrap-span">Special lass="word-wrap-span">Administrative lass="word-wrap-span">Region (SAR) government led by the current lass="word-wrap-span">Chief lass="word-wrap-span">Executive, lass="word-wrap-span">Carrie lass="word-wrap-span">Lam. Ms lass="word-wrap-span">Lam showed a lass="word-wrap-span">catastrophic lack of judgement. lass="word-wrap-span">First, in trying to force through lass="word-wrap-span">amendments to lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s lass="word-wrap-span">extradition laws that (among other things) would allow handing over criminal suspects to the justice system in the mainland: it is lass="word-wrap-span">completely lass="word-wrap-span">incompatible with lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s rule of law.

If that were not bad enough, she then stubbornly refused to respond in any way to the huge and lass="word-wrap-span">initially peaceful protest marches that demanded the scrapping of the bill. lass="word-wrap-span">This was the straw that broke the lass="word-wrap-span">camel’s back and the trigger for more radical protesters to resort to violence.

lass="word-wrap-span">Inevitably, lass="word-wrap-span">The police have lass="word-wrap-span">borne lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">brunt of protesters’ rage and lass="word-wrap-span">frustration. lass="word-wrap-span">They should not be put in lass="word-wrap-span">The position of having to defend lass="word-wrap-span">fundamentally lass="word-wrap-span">indefensible lass="word-wrap-span">lapses in government policy. lass="word-wrap-span">The police have come under increasing pressure to deal with escalating violence on lass="word-wrap-span">The part of a very small group of protesters.

lass="word-wrap-span">Unfortunately, some well documented evidence of the heavy-handed use of force, some at close range and in lass="word-wrap-span">densely populated residential areas, has lass="word-wrap-span">discredited a once widely admired and respected force. I fear it will take years to restore the public confidence that the force enjoyed.

It is difficult, at present, to see how lass="word-wrap-span">The current lass="word-wrap-span">impasse can be broken. lass="word-wrap-span">The government is clearly banking on lass="word-wrap-span">The protests burning lass="word-wrap-span">Themselves out once schools and universities resume lass="word-wrap-span">classes after lass="word-wrap-span">The summer holidays, but this lass="word-wrap-span">grossly underestimates lass="word-wrap-span">The momentum that has built up and is being sustained.

lass="word-wrap-span">While young people are at the vanguard of the protests, the lass="word-wrap-span">disaffection with the current administration spans a very broad spectrum of the community, prompting unprecedented public protests and petitions by professionals in the legal, education, medical and social services sectors, business interests, civil servants, church leaders, the lass="word-wrap-span">elderly and mothers of young children.

In response to government lass="word-wrap-span">insistence that violence lass="word-wrap-span">cease, last weekend’s protests passed off peacefully. lass="word-wrap-span">However Ms lass="word-wrap-span">Lam remains lass="word-wrap-span">intransigent. lass="word-wrap-span">The current situation could be significantly lass="word-wrap-span">defused were she to lass="word-wrap-span">accede to at least two of lass="word-wrap-span">The protesters’ five demands that have broad support: namely lass="word-wrap-span">complete withdrawal of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">extradition bill—at lass="word-wrap-span">The moment it is only suspended—and lass="word-wrap-span">The setting up of an independent commission of lass="word-wrap-span">inquiry into lass="word-wrap-span">The causes of lass="word-wrap-span">The current unrest and its handling by lass="word-wrap-span">The authorities. lass="word-wrap-span">Establishing lass="word-wrap-span">The facts will enable lass="word-wrap-span">The first steps to be taken to heal lass="word-wrap-span">The rift in society.

No one understands why she will not agree to withdraw the bill; this is (or should be) lass="word-wrap-span">entirely within her remit. lass="word-wrap-span">Despite assurances to the lass="word-wrap-span">contrary, the police remain lass="word-wrap-span">adamantly opposed to the concept of an independent lass="word-wrap-span">inquiry which they believe would be primarily targeted at them.

In lass="word-wrap-span">The current situation, moral lass="word-wrap-span">courage and lass="word-wrap-span">decisive, proactive leadership is lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">essential, but lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong is lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">essentially a rudderless ship. lass="word-wrap-span">The captain has left lass="word-wrap-span">The bridge and government policy appears to be lass="word-wrap-span">dictated from Beijing.

If the lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong chief lass="word-wrap-span">executive cannot face up to the tough decisions now required in order to restore good civil lass="word-wrap-span">governance and peace on the streets, then she should step aside. lass="word-wrap-span">Her reputation is in tatters and beyond salvation; lass="word-wrap-span">Her manifest lack of authority is a major lass="word-wrap-span">impediment to resolution of the current lass="word-wrap-span">impasse.

lass="word-wrap-span">While lass="word-wrap-span">There is much about lass="word-wrap-span">The current situation that is profoundly saddening, I am not without hope that, under lass="word-wrap-span">The right leadership, lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong can soon move forward once again. lass="word-wrap-span">This can only happen if lass="word-wrap-span">The central and local SAR governments face up to reality. lass="word-wrap-span">The protest movement, lass="word-wrap-span">composed in large part of well-educated and determined young people, will not back down empty-handed. lass="word-wrap-span">Their future is at stake and lass="word-wrap-span">They are prepared to dig in and fight for it.

lass="word-wrap-span">There are no quick lass="word-wrap-span">fixes. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">debacle over lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">extradition bill has brought into slass="word-wrap-span">harp focus lass="word-wrap-span">The dangers of a government machine, with no electoral mandate, seeking to ride rough-shod over lass="word-wrap-span">The views and interests of ordinary citizens who have no power to vote its leaders out of office.

lass="word-wrap-span">Progress on lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">implementation of full universal suffrage for lass="word-wrap-span">The election of lass="word-wrap-span">The chief lass="word-wrap-span">executive and all members of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong legislature, as promised to lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong people in lass="word-wrap-span">Their constitution, must now be a top priority. lass="word-wrap-span">The government should offer to re-open discussion on constitutional reforms with a view to agreeing on a timetable to achieve this objective.

lass="word-wrap-span">For its part, instead of lass="word-wrap-span">instinctively lass="word-wrap-span">cracking down on the lass="word-wrap-span">democratic movement, the government in Beijing would do well to lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrate some trust in lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong and seek ways to lass="word-wrap-span">harness the energy and determination of its people lass="word-wrap-span">For the greater good of the city and the nation.

________________

lass="word-wrap-span">Anson lass="word-wrap-span">Chan was the lass="word-wrap-span">Chief lass="word-wrap-span">Secretary of lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong, the territory’s most senior civil servant, from 1993 to 2001, serving both the British lass="word-wrap-span">colonial government and the lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong lass="word-wrap-span">Special lass="word-wrap-span">Administrative lass="word-wrap-span">Region government.
